awd_titl_txt: Conference on Human-Centered Approaches to Artificial Intelligence Literacy in Informal Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
The New York Hall of Science (NYSCI) will convene a two-day participatory design conference of to identify research and education opportunities in informal settings for supporting literacy concerning Artificial Intelligence (AI), especially for diverse and underserved youth whose communities are impacted by the bias in some AI processes. AI uses computer systems that simulate human intelligence. AI systems impact nearly every aspect of daily living, performing tasks underlying navigation apps, facial recognition, e-payments, and social media. AI can perpetuate inequities and biased outcomes in the culture at large. The conference will explore how to promote engagement and conceptual learning among youth about how AI works and what skills are needed to critically use and apply AI. The conference will also explore ways to support the interests of diverse and underserved children and youth in shaping AI and joining the growing STEM workforce that will use AI in their professions. 

The conference will identify key features and needs with respect to AI literacy and explore the specific roles that informal learning can play in advancing AI literacy for youth in diverse and underserved communities. Participants in the conference will include designers, learning scientists, researchers, informal and formal educators, and science center professionals. Attendees will work in separate teams and as a group to explore and critique existing AI tools and learning frameworks, discuss lessons learned from promising AI literacy programs, and identify design principles and future directions for research. Specific attention will be paid to informal mechanisms of engagement, promising networks, and research-practice partnerships that take advantage of the unique affordances of informal learning and community services to accelerate AI literacy for historically excluded youth. The insights gained from this work will result in a set of research and programmatic priorities for informal institutions to promote AI literacy in culturally responsive ways. The resulting published guide and community events will broadly disseminate priorities and design principles generated by this convening to help informal learning institutions and community learning organizations identify both assets and priorities for addressing diversity, equity, access, and inclusion issues related to AI literacy. 

This research project is funded by the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program, which seeks to (a) advance new approaches to and evidence-based understanding of the design and development of STEM learning in informal environments; (b) provide multiple pathways for broadening access to and engagement in STEM learning experiences; (c) advance innovative research on and assessment of STEM learning in informal environments; and (d) engage the public of all ages in learning STEM in informal environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The New York Hall of Science hosted a two-day conference to advance our understanding of and approach to AI literacy in informal education. Using a human-centered framework, this participatory conference fostered critical discussions within the informal learning community, creating an inclusive space for diverse participation in exploring the role informal learning can play in AI literacy efforts. The diversity in perspectives, expertise, and cultural backgrounds of attendees created unique opportunities for cross-sector collaborations and engagement with varied audiences. 

The conference consisted of presentations, group discussions, and hands-on program development sessions. The core issues addressed were, a) promoting engagement and conceptual understanding about AI and the foundational skills needed to critically use and apply it, b) exploring and shifting learners’ attitudes toward AI and its impact; and c) identifying strategies for fostering children’s agency in interrogating, intervening, and shaping AI to become AI-enabled workers and community members. 

Key outcomes from the conference included the development of a human-centered framework and a core set of values and design principles for informal AI literacy, centering on promoting agency through using, interrogating, and designing AI. These principles, shaped by attendees’ cross-disciplinary experiences, provide guidelines for future AI literacy initiatives in museum programs, community-based learning organizations, and exhibitions. The principles are, 

  • Design AI to support, not harm, humanity.

  • Encourage critical questioning of AI’s role in our lives.

  • Foster creativity, critical thinking, and AI skills.

  • Ensure equitable access to AI and address diverse needs.

  • Build communities of care and repair around AI’s societal impacts.

  • Highlight the role of informal learning in AI literacy.

  • Incorporate joy, play, and exploration into AI learning.

  • Prioritize social justice and multilingual access to tools and resources.

In addition, the attendees created eight innovative ideas for future programs in informal learning that focused on humanistic AI and illustrated these principles. The team also created a project website that contains the details and lesson-learned from the conference that can be easily accessed.
